results.title: Lenin's secret files
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Time watch”.
‘Lenin’s secret files’ is part of an acclaimed investigative history series from the BBC which pursues new evidence and research of familiar historical events and figures. In this program the ethnic background, family, political ruthlessness and illness of Vladimir Illich Lenin, who, in 1917 led the Russian Revolution, are followed. It uses the personal archives of Lenin - which have only been accessible since the collapse of communism, to present a definitive portrait of one of history’s key figures.

results.title: Lenin's Russia
results.creator_credit: Richard Dunn and Educational Media International
results.brief_description: This film adopts a novel approach to Lenin’s Russia by using a debate between two university students on the use of book and film resources to investigate the period. The film includes authentic newsreel footage. It is involved in examining problems of historical methodology. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Lenin's revolution
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History 1917-1967”.
Describes the background to the Russian revolution of 1917, Lenin’s intentions and policies and the consolidation of the Bolsheviks in power. Commentary by Brian Redhead. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Lend Us a Hand
results.brief_description: Like all small towns, Mirboo North survives on the support of its dedicated volunteers. This film features some of the many volunteer groups that are active in Mirboo North. From the local Op Shop to the Wednesday Warriors and the Mirboo North Times, it captures the community spirit of giving.

results.title: Lena the glassblower: Sweden
results.creator_credit: Peter Rowe, Fred Harris, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Sunrise Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World cultures and youth”.
The story of Lena, a 17-year-old girl who decides to become a glassblower against the wishes of her parents, who want her to take up tertiary education. As well as dealing positively with this conflict, the film shows many aspects of the craft of glassblowing - in particular, that carried out at the Orrefors establishment in Sweden. Suitable for upper primary, lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Len Lye: interview with Tyler Cann
results.brief_description: Tyler Cann, Curator of the Len Lye Collection at the Govett-Brewster Art Gallery in New Plymouth, New Zealand, visited ACMI during the Len Lye exhibition. Tyler Cann spoke about Len Lye’s influential and enduring body of work noting that this retrospective at ACMI is the largest and most comprehensive exhibition of the artist’s work to date. He focuses on particular works, some of which were reconstructed specifically for the ACMI exhibition.

results.title: Len Lye's films. Vol. 1: Free radicals
results.creator_credit: Len Lye and Len Lye Foundation
results.brief_description: This collection of short animated films spans 50 years of Len Lye’s experimental filmmaking. All but ‘Rhythm’ (1957) use ‘direct film’ techniques dispensing with the camera to paint and scratch directly onto the film surface. Lye’s abstract films influenced and led the way for experimental filmmaking and filmmakers such as Norman McLaren and Stan Brakhage amongst many others. He incorporated musical soundtracks of mostly tribal and percussive themes that reflected his interest in rhythm and movement as in ‘Free radicals’ (1958) and ‘Particles in Space’(1979) as well as jazz and blues soundtracks (the music of Tal Farlow and Sonny Terry were also used).

results.title: Lemonheads: two weeks in Australia
results.creator_credit: Jesse Peretz, Catherine Smith and Atlantic
results.brief_description: The independant US band The Lemonheads first received mainstream attention when their album “It’s A Shame About Ray” broke through into the Top 40. We casually follow the band around Australia during the 1992 tour to promote the album. Utilising cinema verite techniques this program includes interviews with the band and live performances of many of their songs. It also features the promotional videos to a number of songs including: “It’s a Shame about Ray”, “Confetti”, “My Drug Buddy” and their unique version of Simon & Garfunkle’s “Mrs Robinson”.

results.title: Lemonade Joe [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Oldrich Lipsky, Jaroslav Jilovec and Filmove Studio Barrandov
results.brief_description: A Czech musical western that spoofs American cinema with obvious affection and demonstrates how the Czech New Wave film movement of the 1960s wasn’t limited to ruminations on the history, politics and art of Eastern Europe. Lemonade Joe (Karel Fiala) is the good-natured lemonade salesman who teams up with a temperance leader, the sweet blond Winnifred (Olga Schoberova), to defeat a local saloon and den of prostitution. With his capitalistic know-how and her ideological piety, they believe that they’ll soon have all of Arizona trading whisky for lemonade. Composed largely in whimsical sing-song rhyme with the characters breaking into song at every opportunity, the dialogue and tunes arise from a uniquely Czech interpretation of the American Western. In Czech with English subtitles.
